record.Title: Tokio Cafe in the Japanese Village at the lower end of the Pay Streak, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, 1909.
record.Notes: On verso of photograph: Tokio Cafe on what was called the Pay Streak- roast beef sandwiches 10 cents. The lower end of the Pay Streak. The promenade at the left of the picture runs along the shore of Portage Bay of Lake Union to about 15th Avenue Northeast in the extreme distance. View looking northwest. There were about eleven of these little oriental type booths running up the center of the Pay Streak.<br><br>PH Coll 727.715

record.Title: Dignitaries at the Igorrote Village, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, 1909.
record.Notes: On verso of image: Dr. Mark A. Matthews, Gov. Marion E. Hay, J.E. Chilberg, the manager of Igorrotes concession, Judge Thomas Burke. Committee appointed to investigate the G string uniforms of the Igorottes. Rev. Mark Matthews cast the final vote in their favor.

record.Title: Court of Honor showing the Geyser Basin, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, 1909.
record.Notes: On verso of photograph: Frosh Pond or the Fountain Basin, looking almost due north. record.Title: Reno Nevada contest delegation, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, 1909.
record.Notes: Two hundred and eight newspaper parties from thirty-five states as well as Canada, Alaska, the Yukon and Hawaii will visit the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition between now and Oct. 15. D.B. Duncombe, who will have charge of the entertainment of these parties, has been assured of the attendance of that number of delegations by the newspapers conducting contests, which result in the winners getting a free trip to the exposition ...As a result of these contests ... the exposition has received hundreds of columns of free advertising. Every day for three months many of the papers gave an entire page and in some instances two pages to announcing the contests which would result in the successful contestants getting a free trip to the ""Seattle Exposition"" as the A.Y.P. seems to be quite generally called in the East.
record.SubjectsLCSH: Portraits, Group--Washington (State)--Seattle; Women--Washington (State)--Seattle; Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.); Exhibitions--Washington (State)--Seattle

record.Title: Commemorative plaque, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Inscription on plaque reads: On these grounds was held between June 1st and October 16th 1909 the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition and this tablet is erected by the Seattle Chamber of Commerce as a testimonial to those citizens of Seattle who from a sense of civic loyalty and a great personal sacrifice, created and carried to success an exposition of lasting benefit not only to this city but to the entire Northwest. But far more important than all other advantages resulting from such an exhibition is the inspiring example of unselfish and disinterested public service which these citizens, without material reward or the hope thereof, have given to their city. Such men are the proudest possession of any community and the surest guarantee of its prosperity and greatness.<br><br>PH Coll 778.53
record.SubjectsLCSH: Plaques--Washington (State)--Seattle; Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.); Exhibitions--Washington (State)--Seattle

record.Title: Santa Cruz contest delegation, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, 1909.
record.Notes: Two hundred and eight newspaper parties from thirty-five states as well as Canada, Alaska, the Yukon and Hawaii will visit the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition between now and Oct. 15. D.B. Duncombe, who will have charge of the entertainment of these parties, has been assured of the attendance of that number of delegations by the newspapers conducting contests, which result in the winners getting a free trip to the exposition ...As a result of these contests ... the exposition has received hundreds of columns of free advertising. Every day for three months many of the papers gave an entire page and in some instances two pages to announcing the contests which would result in the successful contestants getting a free trip to the ""Seattle Exposition"" as the A.Y.P. seems to be quite generally called in the East.
record.SubjectsLCSH: Portraits, Group--Washington (State)--Seattle; Women--Washington (State)--Seattle; Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.); Exhibitions--Washington (State)--Seattle

record.Title: Montana Contest delegation, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, 1909.
record.Notes: Two hundred and eight newspaper parties from thirty-five states as well as Canada, Alaska, the Yukon and Hawaii will visit the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition between now and Oct. 15. D.B. Duncombe, who will have charge of the entertainment of these parties, has been assured of the attendance of that number of delegations by the newspapers conducting contests, which result in the winners getting a free trip to the exposition ...As a result of these contests ... the exposition has received hundreds of columns of free advertising. Every day for three months many of the papers gave an entire page and in some instances two pages to announcing the contests which would result in the successful contestants getting a free trip to the ""Seattle Exposition"" as the A.Y.P. seems to be quite generally called in the East.<br><br>On verso of image: Montana Contest Party 1909<br><br>PH Coll 727.868
record.SubjectsLCSH: Portraits, Group--Washington (State)--Seattle; Women--Washington (State)--Seattle; Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.); Exhibitions--Washington (State)--Seattle

record.Title: Court of Honor, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, 1909.
record.Notes: On verso of photograph: This, the Court of Honor, is at the head of Rainier Vista, with the Cascades showing in the immediate left front, above the Fountain Basin. If this picture had been taken on a clear day, Lakw [sic] Washington would have shown beyond the timber in the background with Mt. Rainier, in all its glory, standing out in the far background.<br><br>Frosh Pond was known as Geyser Basin at the time of the AYPE.<br><br>Caption on image: x5951<br><br>PH Coll 727.90

record.Title: Children of All Nations Day, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Eighteen foreign children, most of them from the Orient, making their homes on the Pay Streak at the exposition, attired in their native garb and paraded around the grounds in rickshaws as if royal personages, produced an attraction at the fair this afternoon different from anything that has been given heretofore. Each child carried the flag of the nation he represents and while at dinner at the Nikko Cafe had the name of the country of which he is a native conspicuously displayed above his chair. There were children from Japan, China, Assyria, Egypt, Morocco, Alaska, Hawaii, Siam, Labrador, Siberia and other countries, and Kuchi Beki, caterer arranged to have distinctive dishes of each nationality on the big table.(Seattle Times, 7/24/1909)<br><br>On verso of photograph: Children of All Nations Day
record.SubjectsLCSH: Bands--Washington (State)--Seattle; Pay Streak (Seattle,Wash.); Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.); Exhibitions--Washington (State)--Seattle

record.Title: International Union of the American Republics flags, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, 1909.
record.Notes: Caption on image: Flags of the countries composing the International Union of the American Republics (Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909)<br><br>The International Bureau of American Republics is maintained by twenty-one American Republics, including the United States, for the development of Pan-American commerce, friendship and peace. The new building, to be completed in September 1909, will cost $1,000,000. The officers are: John Barrett, Director, F.J. Yanes, Secretary.<br><br>PH Coll 777.x.Advert.13

record.Title: Olympia High School students working in the model kitchen and workshop areas in the Educational Building exhibit, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, 1909
record.Notes: Shows Domestic Science Kitchen and Manual Training Department. On verso of image: Olympia High School at A.Y.P.E. View of shop and kitchen. Letter accompanying photograph: The manual training boys of the Olympia High School began on the 11 of June to finish and furnish three bare rooms - shop, kitchen & dining room. Picture shows shop and kitchen with boys and girls at work. Open sides for spectators. Boys are building work benches, girls taking notes at beginning of demonstration lesson. Boys have built cooking tables doing gas pipe cutting and fitting. These rooms will be completely finished and furnished during the summer.<br><br>Caption on image: x2955<br><br>PH Coll 727.309

record.Title: Children of All Nations Day, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Eighteen foreign children, most of them from the Orient, making their homes on the Pay Streak at the exposition, attired in their native garb and paraded around the grounds in rickshaws as if royal personages, produced an attraction at the fair this afternoon different from anything that has been given heretofore. Each child carried the flag of the nation he represents and while at dinner at the Nikko Cafe had the name of the country of which he is a native conspicuously displayed above his chair. There were children from Japan, China, Assyria, Egypt, Morocco, Alaska, Hawaii, Siam, Labrador, Siberia and other countries, and Kuchi Beki, caterer arranged to have distinctive dishes of each nationality on the big table.(Seattle Times, 7/24/1909)<br><br> On verso of photograph: Children of all Nations Day, AYP Band
record.SubjectsLCSH: Bands--Washington (State)--Seattle; Pay Streak (Seattle,Wash.); Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.); Exhibitions--Washington (State)--Seattle

record.Title: Salt Lake contest party, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, July 21, 1909.
record.Notes: Two hundred and eight newspaper parties from thirty-five states as well as Canada, Alaska, the Yukon and Hawaii will visit the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition between now and Oct. 15. D.B. Duncombe, who will have charge of the entertainment of these parties, has been assured of the attendance of that number of delegations by the newspapers conducting contests, which result in the winners getting a free trip to the exposition ...As a result of these contests ... the exposition has received hundreds of columns of free advertising. Every day for three months many of the papers gave an entire page and in some instances two pages to announcing the contests which would result in the successful contestants getting a free trip to the ""Seattle Exposition"" as the A.Y.P. seems to be quite generally called in the East.<br><br>On verso of image: Salt Lake [illeg.]Contest Party 7/21/09
record.SubjectsLCSH: Portraits, Group--Washington (State)--Seattle; Women--Washington (State)--Seattle; Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.); Exhibitions--Washington (State)--Seattle

record.Title: Court of Honor, Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, June 1909
record.Notes: On verso of photograph: The present Frosh Pond which was the central pool and fountain basin on Rainier Vista. The Government Building, at the head of Rainier Vista, with the tall column with eagle with raised wings directly in its front, is at right center. The cascades shown in another picture ran from in front of this column toward, but not into, Frosh Pond. This view is looking northwest.<br><br>Frosh Pond was known as Geyser Basin at the time of the AYPE.<br><br>Caption on image: x1494<br><br>PH Coll 727.88
record.SubjectsLCSH: United States Government Building (Seattle, Wash.); Exhibition buildings--Washington (State)--Seattle; Frosh Pond (Wash.); Fountains--Washington (State)--Seattle; Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.); Exhibitions--Washington (State)--Seattle

record.Title: Painting by C.A. Holland representing the Alaska Yukon Pacific Exposition, Seattle, 1909.
record.Notes: Caption on image: Reproduction of Alaska-Yukon-Pacific allegorical painting. C.A. Holland 1908. Copyrighted.<br><br>On verso of image: The dominant figures stand for Alaska, Yukon and the Pacific. The Shell, laden with gold from Alaska and the Yukon, the fruit and flowers from the Pacific states, represent the shipping interests. The Salmon portray the fishing industries. The Totem Poles stand for a by-gone age giving place to a new creation indicated by the outlines in the background of the Exposition Buildings of 1909, dimly seen in their new glory. The original painting will be on exhibition in its own building on the grounds.PH Coll 777.x.Exhibit.2
record.SubjectsLCSH: Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition (1909 : Seattle, Wash.)--Paintings; Exhibitions--Washington (State)--Seattle

record.Notes: This photograph was taken by one of the many amateur photographers allowed to photograph the grounds, buildings and exhibits of the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition. By purchasing a day pass, an amateur photographer with a camera smaller then 6" x 8" was allowed to take unlimited pictures inside the exposition. <br> <br> Handwritten on verso: Eskimo Village. <br><br> PH Coll 369.23

record.Title: Chandelar Avenue, the U.S. Government Building and Hawaii Building, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Beverly Bennett Dobbs was born in 1868 near Marshall, Missouri. In 1888 Dobbs moved to Bellingham, Washington and operated a photography studio there for 12 years. In 1900 Dobbs moved to Nome, Alaska and continued to work as a photographer capturing images of Nome, the Seward Peninsula and Inuit people. In 1909, Dobbs started the Dobbs Alaska Moving Picture Co. and began making films about the Gold Rush. By 1914, Dobbs had moved back to Seattle and was creating more films through the Dobbs Totem Film Company which he ran until his death in 1937. <br><br> PH Coll 755.1

record.Title: Oregon State Building with visitors gathered in front, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Beverly Bennett Dobbs was born in 1868 near Marshall, Missouri. In 1888 Dobbs moved to Bellingham, Washington and operated a photography studio there for 12 years. In 1900 Dobbs moved to Nome, Alaska and continued to work as a photographer capturing images of Nome, the Seward Peninsula and Inuit people. In 1909, Dobbs started the Dobbs Alaska Moving Picture Co. and began making films about the Gold Rush. By 1914, Dobbs had moved back to Seattle and was creating more films through the Dobbs Totem Film Company which he ran until his death in 1937. <br> <br> Caption on image: A.Y.P. 09. Dobbs. <br><br> PH Coll 755.17

record.Notes: This photograph was taken by one of the many amateur photographers allowed to photograph the grounds, buildings and exhibits of the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition. record.Title: Entrance gate to White City amusement park in Madison Park with a young girl walking under the archway toward the admission booth, Seattle, Washington, ca. 1908
record.Notes: The White City amusement park opened in about 1908 and then closed in 1912. The admission price was 10 cents. It is likely that the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition overshadowed it which lead to its brief life. The park had a roller coaster and a Ferris wheel, some side shows and performers. The most popular ride was the miniature railway called the Lake Shore Railway. When the AYPE came some of the attractions were moved over to be part of the exposition.<br><br>Caption on mount: Entrance to White City. Seattle, Wash. <br><br> PH Coll 757.1

record.Title: Exposition grounds before construction showing residential houses in the background, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, ca. 1908
record.Notes: This photograph was taken by one of the many amateur photographers allowed to photograph the grounds, buildings and exhibits of the Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition. By purchasing a day pass, an amateur photographer with a camera smaller then 6" x 8" was allowed to take unlimited pictures inside the exposition.<br><br>Caption on mount: Grounds. Seattle.<br><br> PH Coll 757.5

record.Title: California State Building, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Eugene M. Weaver was born in Circleville, Ohio in 1879. During the summer of 1909, Weaver and his wife Zana Taylor took a trip to Seattle and Canada and photographed their journey. The couple settled in Sonoma County in 1911 and operated a vineyard and orchard in the Dry Creek district. Weaver ran the orchard and vineyard till one year before his death in 1952. <br><br> Handwritten on verso: California. A.Y.P.E. <br><br> PH Coll 772.1

record.Title: Rear Admiral Hikojiro Ijichi, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Orville J. Rognon started as a photographer in 1908 at Webster and Steven and in 1911 became a partner with Frank Nowell. Rognon moved to Vancouver, B.C. in 1913 and worked at the Canadian Photo Company. He then formed a partnership with Leonard Frank in 1918 to create the Commercial Photo Company. Rognon was probably hired by Frank Nowell, the official photographer for the Exposition. <br><br> Handwritten on verso: Vice Admiral Ijichi of Japanese Navy.<br><br> PH Coll 779.1

record.Title: Native American totem poles, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Indian Totem Poles. Alaska. <br><br>Printed on verso: The old Indian legends associated with Totem poles are interesting to every visitor to Alaska. Some are beautifully carved, each figure representing an incident in the life or family history of the Indian. <br><br> No. 575. Hopf Bros. Co. Importers. Seattle, Wash. <br><br> Handwritten on verso: Seattle, Wash. 7-29-09. Dear Inez, We are enjoying the Exposition. The weather is fine here. We're so tired we did not go out today. We are nicely located in a private home. Hope this will find all well. Best wishes to all. Your friend, Mrs. R.J.<br><br> Postmarked: Seattle, Washington. July 30th 1909. Exposition Station. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Hopf.575

record.Title: European Foreign Exhibits Building, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1908
record.Notes: Caption on image: A portion of the European Foreign Exhibit Building. <br><br> Printed on verso: Portland Post Card Co. Seattle, Wash. and Portland, Ore. Official Post Card. Copyrighted 1908. A.Y.P.E. Co. <br><br> Handwritten on verso: Saturday-Oct. 16, 1909. The last day of the A-Y-P Expo is at hand and I must send you a postcard from the fair as a souvenir. The bands are making their rounds in the bldgs for the last time playing good bye pieces. I think too bad it is over so soon. The day is beautiful. My sister has just come. Rec. your letter. Send you all cards. Abbie.<br><br> Postmarked: Seattle, WA. University Station. Oct. 19. <br><br> PH Coll 777 PPCC.32 (See also PH Coll 433.32)

record.Title: Oregon State Building, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: 6101. Oregon State Building. Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Seattle. 1909. <br><br> Printed on verso: Portland Post Card Co. Portland, Ore and Seattle, Wash. <br><br> Dear Sir: If you are interested in Refrigerating or Ice Machinery we would be pleased to have you inspect the Larsen-Baker Ice Machine we have installed in the Oregon State Building when you visit the A.Y.P. Exposition the coming summer. The Cold Storage Rooms containing the entire Oregon exhibit of Apples are cooled with this machine. Yours Respectfully, Phil L. Serwe & Co. Agents. Larsen-Baker Ice Machine Co. 305 Occidental Ave. Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 PPCC.6101a

record.Title: Fine Arts Building, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Fine Arts Palace. <br><br> Printed on verso: 55. The Fine Arts Palace contains in its various halls, 531 paintings and pieces of sculpture. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.55 (See also PH Coll 78.162)

record.Title: George Washington statue covered with draped American flag and surrounded by a crowd of visitors, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Washington Statue. <br><br> Printed on verso: 60. record.Notes: Caption on image: Chehalis County Building. <br><br> Printed on verso: 62. record.Notes: Caption on image: Utah Building. <br><br> Printed on verso: 66. The Utah Building is a reproduction of a section of the Hopi Pueblo, an adobe community dwelling built originally by the Bear and Snake families of the Hopi Indians. Mining, irrigation and the State's specialties are well represented. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. record.Notes: Printed on verso: Eskimo Village. In the Eskimo Village there are Eskimos from Siberia, Alaska and Labrador, and visitors have an opportunity to study the various tribes. record.Title: Baby Incubator exhibit interior, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: The Baby Incubator. <br><br> Printed on verso: 78. The Baby Incubator. In no other way does science enlist our interest and sympathy so much as in its assistance in saving infant life. Within these "machines" are seven little pre-maturely born infants. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.78 (See also PH Coll 78.190)

record.Title: Ferris Wheel, Pay Streak, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Ferris Wheel. <br><br> Printed on verso: 79. The Ferris Wheel, near the head of the Pay Streak, proves a facinating feature. Whether in day-light, when the colors of the exposition and scenery are kaleidoscopic, or at night when countless lights are glowing the scenery from its cars is bewitching. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.79a (See also PH Coll 78.169)

record.Title: Fairy Gorge Tickler, Pay Streak, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Fairy Gorge Tickler. <br><br> Printed on verso: 80. The Fairy Gorge Tickler is the most ridiculous, laughable and tantalizing amusement on the Pay Streak. It's the sensations of the passenger in the descending tubs that make it a winner. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.80 (See also PH Coll 78.191)

record.Title: Five women in geisha outfits standing in a garden, Japanese Village exhibit, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Geisha Girls. <br><br> Printed on verso: 81. Geisha Girls. These pretty Japanese girls are in the Japanese Village, or Streets of Tokyo, on the Pay Streak. They serve patrons with tea and rice cakes in a gentle, polite and inimitable manner. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.81 (See also PH Coll 78.194)

record.Title: Japan Building, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Japan Exhibit Building. <br><br> Printed on verso: 82. The Japan Exhibit Building is one of the largest most expensive and attractive buildings at the Exposition. It is surrounded by forest trees without, and within is filled with the finest and most artistic works ever brought from that country. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.82 (See also PH Coll 78.157)

record.Title: Big Stick, lumber exhibit at the Forestry Building, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: The Big Stick. <br><br> Printed on verso: 84. The Big Stick. The Big Stick is one immense piece of "milled" timber 156 1-2 feet in length, and is one of the things showing the wonderful timber growths of the Pacific Northwest. See it at the Forestry Building. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.84 (See also PH Coll 78.63)

record.Title: Music Pavilion, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Music Pavilion. <br><br> Printed on verso: 89. Muisc Pavilion. This classic Temple of Music is finely embowered among forest trees and surrounded by flowers. In it famous bands discourse music, provided by the Exposition free, the concerts taking place several times daily. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.89 (See also PH Coll 78.150)

record.Title: Spectators at the Natural Amphitheatre, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Natural Amphitheatre. <br><br> Printed on verso: 90. Section of the Natural Amphitheatre. In the Natural Amphitheatre have been gathered twenty-five thousand men and women, where the "rising and sitting" caused a wave of the mass of humanity like the rolling waves of the ocean. The engraving shows a section about one-fifth of the audience. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.90 (See also PH Coll 78.33)

record.Title: Exhibit of gold bars and nuggets, Alaska Building, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: One and a Quarter Million. <br><br> Printed on verso: 91. One and a Quarter Million. Upon a stand within a glass case, within an iron cage, within a classic temple, within the Alaska Building; so secure and yet so easily seen, repose bars and nuggets of pure gold valued at a million and a quarter dollars. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.91 (See also PH Coll 78.118)

record.Title: Main Entrance gate and grounds, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Main Entrance. <br><br> Printed on verso: 92. The Main Entrance. Within the Main Entrance is Puget Plaza leading directly to the Court of Honor, "the Heart of the Exposition." Banks and beds of flowers, which are everywhere to be seen, are here first in evidence. The main entrance is the most imposing and attractive ever erected at an Exposition. <br><br> 1909. The Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. Official Photograph. Published by Robert A. Reid. 488 Arcade. Made in Seattle. <br><br> PH Coll 777 Reid.92 (See also PH Coll 78.13)

record.Title: Formal Gardens looking towards Arctic Circle, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: N.H. Nowell. Official Photographer. Alaska-Yukon-Pacific Exposition. X1551. <br><br> Printed on verso: The top of the Sunken Gardens extending to the southeast from below Frosh Pond. On a clear day one could stand at the railing shown here and look down over the Sunken Gardens (directly back of the camera) and see Lake Washington with Mt. Rainier in view directly down the vista. This view of Mt. Rainier gave the vista its name. <br><br> PH Coll 727.122

record.Title: Large group of Smiths on Auditorium steps for Smith Family Day, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, September 2, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: Smith Family Day. A.Y.P. Exposition. Sept. 2 1909. X3715. <br><br> Handwritten on verso: Four Hundred Smiths. record.Title: Smith Family Day prize winners on Auditorium steps, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, September 2, 1909
record.Notes: Caption on image: The Prize Winners. Smith Family Day. A.Y.P. Exposition. Sept. 2 1909. X3717. <br><br> Handwritten on verso: From left to right. Oldest pair of twins Smith's: Miss Adna H. and Adeline H. Handsomest Smith man: Mr. E.B. Smith. Handsomest married lady: Mrs. N.H. Smith. Homliest Smith man: Jim P. Smith. Handsomest Miss Smith: Miss. Florence M. Smith. Tallest Smith: Mr. Jack Smith. Shortest Smith: Sidney Smith. Slimest Smith or thinnest: Mrs. Harriet Smith. Fattest Smith: Mrs. W.O. Smith. Youngest Smith twins: Vernon and Vincent Smith. Prettiest Smith baby under one year: William Howard Smith. Prettiest Smith baby over one year: Jeanette Smith. (There is also a poem about the Smith family name proceding the winners names) <br><br> PH Coll 727.809

record.Title: Improved Order of Red Men, Alaska-Yukon-Pacific-Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909
record.Notes: The Improved Order of Red Men is a fraternal organization, still in existence, that can be traced back to a 1765 organization called the Sons of Liberty. According to their website, they patterned themselves "after the great Iroquois Confederacy and its democratic body", and they assumed customs and terminology of Native Americans.<br><br>Printed on image x2214<br><br>Ph Coll 727.859

record.Notes: Caption on image: Washington Building <br><br>Printed on verso: 61. record.Notes: Written on verso: Tree cut from Tyee Camp of E.G. English Lumber Co. Timber 4' x 74'. Timber hewed by Jack Davis and helper.
